block.p: The Northrop Corporation reported today that its third- quarter net income rose 26.8 percent, helped by strong sales of its B-2 bomber.

Northrop said it earned $53.8 million, or $1.14 a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $42.4 million, or 90 cents a share, in the 1990 period. Sales rose 22 percent, to $1.55 billion, from $1.27 billion.
The Northrop Corporation reported today that its third- quarter net income rose 26.8 percent, helped by strong sales of its B-2 bomber.

Northrop said it earned $53.8 million, or $1.14 a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $42.4 million, or 90 cents a share, in the 1990 period. Sales rose 22 percent, to $1.55 billion, from $1.27 billion.
Operating profit was higher in each of the company's three main businesses: aircraft; electronics, and missiles and unmanned vehicle systems, said Kent Kresa, the chairman.

Growth in sales of the radar- evading, B-2, which is shaped like a bat, caused the overall profit increase, more than offsetting lower margins on the aircraft parts Northrop builds for fighter and passenger jets.
Besides increased B-2 production, the company's revenue rose in its missile and unmanned vehicle systems segments. But those from its electronics business declined.

Northrop had hoped to lead the team building the Air Force's next-generation advanced tactical fighter. With the loss of the program to a team led by the Lockheed Corporation, and future B-2 financing uncertain, the company's future big-ticket programs are uncertain, although profits and sales are high for now.
Net debt was down, to $559 million in the quarter, 42 percent below the year-earlier figure of $964 million and down 56 percent from its peak of $1.28 billion in June 1989.
Northrop's stock lost 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $23.875.
